article.headline: UCLA 69, Oregon State 61
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- UCLA's offensive performance was woeful until freshman Arron Afflalo rescued the Bruins. Afflalo snapped a tie on a 3-pointer with 1:42 remaining and UCLA defeated Oregon State 69-61 Thursday night to shore up its bid for an at-large berth in the NCAA tournament. "We're inching closer," UCLA coach Ben Howland said. The Bruins (17-9) also helped their seeding in next week's Pac-10 tournament at Staples Center. Their third straight win moved them into a third-place tie with Stanford at 10-7. The Cardinal lost to Washington State 59-48 Thursday night. UCLA hosts Oregon in its regular season finale Saturday. The Bruins were 19-of-22 from the free throw line in the second half, which made up for their 37 percent field-goal shooting. "We missed some good looks early in the game. We were anxious," Howland said. "Then we settled down and really showed maturity." Freshman Jordan Farmar led UCLA with 23 points and assisted on Afflalo's 3-pointer that put the Bruins ahead for good. Farmar tied his career high with seven rebounds and had seven assists. "He controlled the game," Oregon State coach Jay John said. "It's why I voted for him as freshman of the year." Farmar played all but one minute and committed just two turnovers. "I was looking to be aggressive and be a playmaker," he said. "I'm making the right decisions and getting more confident." The Beavers (16-12, 8-9) will make the eight-team conference tournament, but the loss didn't help their NCAA tourney chances. They fell to 0-8 in Pac-10 road games, and will conclude conference play with a crosstown visit to Southern California on Saturday. "Now we need a win. We need to get that USC game," said David Lucas, who led Oregon State with 24 points. Dijon Thompson added 18 points and Afflalo had 12 points and a career-tying nine rebounds. J.S. Nash had a career-high 11 rebounds for the Beavers. The teams played a tight second half, with neither leading by more than five points. Lucas tied the game at 59 on two free throws, then Lamar Hurd scored inside to put the Beavers ahead 61-59. Hurd fouled Farmar, who made both for the final tie of the game at 61. After Nick DeWitz missed, Farmar fired a pass to Afflalo near UCLA's bench and he hit the 3 for a 64-61 lead. "I just relaxed and shot it," said Afflalo, who grabbed a key defensive rebound seconds earlier. "I'm just trying to get instinctive going to the boards. I knew we needed that possession." Thompson made three free throws in a row and Farmar hit two free throws to seal the win. Nash missed with just over a minute left, then Jason Fontenet's 3-point attempt bounced off the side of the rim with 40 seconds left.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover
